We do have something similar in humans though, it's called eyeballs. Why keep our entire heads stationary when our eyes do the job for us.

The reason why Chickens stabilize their head... and also why they jerk their heads around when they walk, is because the way their eyesight has evolved.  Chickens eyes take a little time to focus, so in order to be able to see, they have to stabilize their heads as they move, and then jerk their head so they can refocus.

It's because birds can't move their eyeballs. Try turning your head while not keeping your focus in one place -- your whole vision blurs. To prevent this blur, they keep their field of vision steady by keeping their head still. It's also why birds walk with that funny strut of their head -- they're keeping their head still as long as possible.

Now why they can't move their eyeballs, why that's somehow a better design and hence evolutionary advantage, I have no idea.

I am convinced they do this because they are basically prey - they need to be on the watch for predators. So HOW DO THEY DO THIS? The key is noticing MOTION. Now if your head is moving, EVERYTHING is in RELATIVE MOTION so you CANNOT pick out a Moving Predator. The SOLUTION is to hold the head steady so that any perceived motion is actual motion and possibly be a predator.

Another theory is that their vision may not be a "fast" as ours - they need time to render an image. Again since on the lookout for predators, they need High Resolution which means they have to "use a tripod" to get a long exposure. Of course head stabilization accomplishes this.

I have asked learned people about this and no one has ever alluded to anything resembling an answer - I guess there just isn't profit to be made in such knowledge (LOL).

So who knows, maybe I'm right and maybe you first heard it hear!
It's like Optical Imagine Stabilization (OIS) in smartphones.

Fantastic video. This is a demonstration of something similar to saccades. Saccades are the fast movements that our eyes make to shift attention. We do the same thing as chickens but we do it with out eyes. If we move our heads, our eyes remain stable. Chickens (and pigeons) saccade with their neck and stabilise their heads (rather than their eyes!). Really neat demo!

     The cerebellum is the part of the brain that integrates movement between parts of our body.  Signals from each part of the body are coordinated in the cerebellum so that our eyes can stabilize an image while we move.
     Chickens do not have a developed cerebellum, so they cannot stabilize vision at the level of their eyes.  They must hold their heads steady or everything will be a blur.  That is why they walk with their head held in space and then popping forward after each step...they cannot see while their head is moving in space.  They essentially see in stop motion while moving.
     If you look at a mirror and shake your head side-to-side, you will see that your eyes can stay fixed on your image.  You don't need to consciously look left-right to counter the movement of your head.  That is your cerebellum at work.  In certain brain injuries, or medical illnesses where the brain is herniating down out if the skull (damaging the cerebellum,) people can develop "dolls eyes" where this ability is lost.
     So, don't think of the chicken as having ability that you do not.  See the chicken as compensating for a more primitive brain.

They do this because chickens (and many other birds) cant actively move there eyes. So to stop their vision being blurred all the time from there head moving around, they hold it still as much as possible. Hence why you see them walking how they do; to try and keep their head and vision stationary for as long as they can. Also when you see birds looking around from left to right or vertically, they have to move there whole head, as they cant move just there eyes :)

The reason most birds can do this is that they can barely move their eyes, so to have a stable field of vision (aka not blury) they need to keep their head spatialy fixed for as long as possible and move it as little as possible. Hence the jabbing head motions chicken do while walking. It may also help with spatial awarness (predators) and deepth perception. We on the other hand can keep our eyes fixed on one spot, just look at yourself in the mirror and move your head from side to side ;)

Well, most birds can't actually move their eyes around in the sockets (why they are always cocking their heads about). So the stationary head is needed just to steady their eyes long enough to focus on an object. Mammals have rounder and proportionally smaller eyes that have musculature built into the eye socket that steadies the eyes as the head moves around.

Knowledge is power!

Birds are not able to track objects with eye muscles, so they have to use their necks instead. Humans, on the other hand, are very good at tracking objects with their eyes. You can move an object around, or your body around, and your eyes will follow the object extremely well. Just like the chicken can keep it's head pointing in the same position, humans can keep their eyes pointing in the same position.

I think the reason a chicken will hold it's head like that is to get a better view of it's surroundings. Motion is generally easier to see if your perspective isn't moving, so holding it's head still between steps helps to see motion between steps. (See motion very well between steps and very badly while stepping rather than seeing motion only fairly well constantly.)

This is false.
Chickens ARE able to move their eyes. Their very long neck allows some birds to keep their head still which provides superior visual acuity to compensating via eye motion.

Head bobbing is the result of holding the head still as long as possible. During the thrust phase the chicken moves its eyes to compensate, but keeps them still during the hold phase.

Source: SACCADIC EYE MOVEMENTS ARE COORDINATED WITH HEAD MOVEMENTS IN WALKING CHICKENS BY DAVID W. PRATT

The reason chickens do this is because they can't move their eyes relative to their heads.  Thus, just like how our eyes are able to stay stable and focused on a single point in space even as our head's are in motion, a chicken's head does the same thing relative to its body.  If the chicken couldn't do this, its vision would be constantly blurry and unstable.

It is a proprietary mechanism purposed to allow the chicken to detect movement as both a predator and prey. 

If you look closely as they walk, you will see the head actually stays in one place while the body walks past it. It then is jerked forward and put in front of the body and the body walks past it again.

This behavior keeps the head still and in one spot as long as possible so the bird is able to see things more clearly and focus on one spot for a longer period of time; especially purpo

Yes, this is called the vestibulo-ocular reflex I'm told

if you look carefully enough at the veins on your eyeball and twist your head, you can see that your eyeball twists to remain flat and rotate to maintain a fixed image in our version of the chicken reflex (in a mirror)

if you look carefully enough at the veins on your eyeball and twist your head, you can see that your eyeball twists to remain flat and rotate to maintain a fixed image in our version of the chicken reflex

the chicken doesn't really know where her head is, it's a reflex.

it's the bird version of our head rotation/eye rotation reflex.  as you turn your head while looking at something stationary, nerves in your ears (semi circular canals) pick up the rotation and apply a counter rotation to your eyes.  since your eyes can look in any direction to the front, this is sensible for tracking targets.

birds have eyes practically fixed in their head, so the same reflex works on their neck muscles

Actually, chicken's and pigeons's eyes can't handle fast movment....

Do you know WHY they can do it? Watch pigeons when they walk, they move the head back an forth. Same reason.

Chicken and pigeons can't handle movement. Their "frame rate" is way to slow. If a pigeon makes a step forward it moves the head back in order to see things clear. The chicken tried to keep the head in one position for the same reason.

If the would not to that, that would see everything blurred.

MY DAD figured out what goes on here .. I remember Pa explaining why a chicken struts the way chickens do.  It's all a matter of perspective.  With it's head relatively close to the ground - things seem blurry - difficult/impoosible  to spot specks of food.  Chicken stabilizes head and then darts head forward twice as fast as it stepped forward.  In short - provides visual acuity while chicken is on the move.  Chicken is not forced to stop in order to have a good look at something.  10-4
